headline: Even In Saudi Arabia, Donald Trump Will Still Get His Steak With Ketchup

article: President Donald Trumpâ€™s love of eating well-done steak with lashings of ketchup is well-documented (and often maligned).So much so that the caterers preparing the official meals during his upcoming visit to Saudi Arabia are reportedly planning to include it on the menu.They will offer Trump his preferred dish alongside traditional local cuisine such as lamb and rice, according to The Associated Press. It is â€œpart of a worldwide effort to accommodate Americaâ€™s homebody president,â€ the news agency notes.Twitter users seemed to be incredulous when they heard the news:Thereâ€™s no word, however, on whether Trumpâ€™s Saudi hosts plan to provide him with the equivalent of the red desk button the president pushes to instruct a butler to bring him Coca-Cola.Trump sets off on Friday for his first official trip as president to the Middle East and Western Europe. headline: Democrats Warn Trump Administration Against Killing Barack Obama's Retirement Rule
short descr: The White House has delayed a regulation meant to save consumers billions of dollars on their retirement plans, putting it in limbo.
image_caption(s): A group of Senate Democrats have noted in a letter to the labor secretary that President Donald Trump has ordered an updated â€œeconomic and legal analysisâ€ of the rule before anything happens to it.
article: President Donald Trump last month delayed a new rule that would require financial advisors to act in their clientsâ€™ best interests when they steer them toward retirement plans. Congressional Democrats warned Friday that the administration was considering killing the rule for good before even doing its own analysis.A group of Senate Democrats said in a letter they sent Friday to Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta that they were alarmed by claims from a retirement advisorsâ€™ lobby that he had made stifling the so-called â€œfiduciary ruleâ€ a â€œnumber one priority.â€ The American Retirement Association reported last week that Acosta had said he was looking to â€œfreeze the ruleâ€ in a way that would â€œstick.â€ Sens. Patty Murray (D-Wash.), Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Cory Booker (D-N.J.) noted in their letter to Acosta that Trump himself had ordered an updated â€œeconomic and legal analysisâ€ of the rule before anything happens to it.â€œInstead of meeting with all stakeholders and considering multiple points of view, you appear to have prejudged the outcome of the review your agency was tasked with conducting,â€ they wrote. â€œIn fact, it seems as though you have already arrived at your decision.â€The fiduciary rule was a major regulation that former President Barack Obama issued in 2015. Until it goes into effect, the financial advisors who help people with 401(k) plans and retirement accounts are not legally obligated to act in their clientsâ€™ best interests the way many other financial advisors are. That gives them the leeway to steer clients toward high-fee investments even if those arenâ€™t necessarily the best products under the circumstances.Warren and other Democrats say the fiduciary rule will save consumers billions of dollars a year by removing a clear conflict of interest for the advisors. But Wall Street groups have fought the regulation ever since it was conceived, and the new White House halted it before it could go into effect in April as planned. A member of Trumpâ€™s economic council had lobbied against the rule on behalf of Fidelity, one of the countryâ€™s largest investment managers, before joining the White House. The new implementation date for the fiduciary rule was pushed back to June, though Senate Republicans have asked Acosta to push back the rollout even further. Warren grilled Acosta over the rule during his confirmation hearing in March, trying to pin him down on his plans for it. â€œWill you protect workers saving for retirement from financial advisors who would cheat them?â€ she asked him in a long back and forth.Acosta wouldnâ€™t indicate where he stood on the rule, saying only that he would follow Trumpâ€™s orders to review all regulations currently on the books.

headline: Trump Reportedly Bragged To Russians About Firing 'Nut Job' FBI Director
short descr: The latest bombshell out of the White House in a week of epic leaks.
image_caption(s): WASHINGTON, D.C., USA - MAY 10, 2017: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, US President Donald Trump, and Russian Ambassador to the United States Sergei Kislyak (L-R) talking during a meeting in the Oval Office at the White House. Alexander Shcherbak/TASS (Photo by Alexander Shcherbak\TASS via Getty Images)
article: WASHINGTON â€• A pair of bombshell reports on Friday threaten to overshadow President Donald Trumpâ€™s first overseas trip and further embroil his administration and presidency in scandal.The New York Times reported Trump told Russian officials that he felt â€œgreat pressure because of Russiaâ€ that he said was taken off when he fired FBI Director James Comey. Minutes later, the Washington Post reported that investigators are looking at a close Trump adviser as part of their probe into possible ties between Russia and Trumpâ€™s campaign.Trump met with Russian officials on May 10 after firing Comey the evening before. At the meeting, Trump told them he was not under investigation and bashed Comey, the Times reported.â€œI just fired the head of the F.B.I. He was crazy, a real nut job,â€ Trump said, according to notes of the meeting read to the Times.Trump and the White House have repeatedly contradicted themselves over the reasoning for Comeyâ€™s firing, which took place as he led a probe into Russian influence into the U.S. election and potential ties to his campaign. The New York Times report is further evidence that Trump fired the FBI director at least in part to end the investigation â€• something thatâ€™s only served to bring more attention to it.The White House did not refute the Timesâ€™ report, but press secretary Sean Spicer said it wasnâ€™t the â€œreal story.â€ â€œThe President has always emphasized the importance of making deals with Russia as it relates to Syria, Ukraine, defeating ISIS and other key issues for the benefit and safety of the American people,â€ Spicer said in a statement. â€œBy grandstanding and politicizing the investigation into Russiaâ€™s actions, James Comey created unnecessary pressure on our ability to engage and negotiate with Russia,â€ Spicer continued. â€œThe investigation would have always continued, and obviously, the termination of Comey would not have ended it. Once again, the real story is that our national security has been undermined by the leaking of private and highly classified conversations.â€Not only did firing Comey not get investigators off Trumpâ€™s back, but the investigation into possible ties between Russia and his campaign also includes a close adviser, the Washington Post reported, citing unnamed officials.Key targets of the investigation until now have reportedly included former Trump national security adviser Michael Flynn and also former Trump campaign honcho Paul Manafort, two people who were part of Trumpâ€™s campaign but are not currently part of the administration. Flynn resigned in February after having lied to investigators about his contacts with Russian ambassador Sergei Kislyak, who was one of the Russian officials Trump met at the White house on May 10. Also during Trumpâ€™s meeting with the Russian officials, he reportedly disclosed â€œhighly classified informationâ€ that â€œjeopardized a critical source of intelligence on the Islamic State,â€ the Washington Post reported.  Federal prosecutors have issued grand jury subpoenas related to the investigation into Flynn. White House officials initially claimed that Trump fired Comey on the advice of Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and released a memo by the official voicing concerns about the FBI directorâ€™s behavior, including his handling of an investigation into 2016 Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.But Trump publicly said soon after that he made the decision ahead of time, and acknowledged the Russia investigation was part of his decision. â€œI was going to fire Comey, knowing there was no good time to do it,â€ he told Lester Holt. â€œAnd in fact when I decided to just do it, I said to myself, I said, â€˜You know, this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story, itâ€™s an excuse by the Democrats for having lost an election.â€™â€Rosenstein contradicted White House officialsâ€™ initial claims as well. He told members of Congress this week that he knew Trump was going to fire Comey before he wrote his memo.This week, Trump repeatedly called the Russian investigation a â€œwitch hunt.â€

headline: Congress' Weed Guy Grapples With The Trump Administration
short descr: Earl Blumenauer tries to pass the peace pipe between Washington and the cannabis industry
image_caption(s): Attorney General Jeff Sessions' views on marijuana have rattled the cannabis industry.
article: WASHINGTON â€• Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) has been selling weed for years. Actually, letâ€™s rephrase: Blumenauer, the bespectacled, bow tie-clad, bicycle-riding lawmaker whose district covers much of â€• where else â€• Portland, has been one of Americaâ€™s most outspoken public officials on liberalizing Americaâ€™s marijuana laws.It now has fallen on Blumenauer to partake in a different type of weed dealing: serving as an unofficial liaison between official Washington and a cannabis industry that is, even by its own vigilant standards, pretty spooked by the prospect of a federal crackdown on it.Though voters in eight states voted to legalize recreational or medical marijuana consumption in November, Donald Trumpâ€™s election and the confirmation of Jeff Sessions, an outspoken marijuana critic, as attorney general has stepped on a lot of buzzes.â€œThe Trump presidency has sent shockwaves virtually everywhere,â€ Blumenauer told HuffPost this week, â€œand it has been an area of special concern for people who deal with marijuana because it appears that Jeff Sessions is no great friend of the industry.â€â€œI think people are kind of torn,â€ Blumenauer said. â€œThey see this amazing groundswell of support for state legal marijuana â€• weâ€™ve seen a huge shift in public opinion â€• but theyâ€™re apprehensive and they should be.â€Marijuana remains classified a schedule one narcotic under the 1970 Controlled Substances Act, meaning the federal government deem it to have a â€œhigh potential for abuseâ€ and â€œhas no currently accepted medical use.â€ That puts it in the same class as heroin and flies in the face of decades of research.Overall, twenty-nine states and the District of Columbia have legalized some form of marijuana consumption. The Obama administration took an increasingly hands-off approach to federal enforcement of marijuana laws, crystallized by a 2013 Department of Justice memorandum known as the Cole Memo, which effectively let marijuana policy up to the states.The Trump administration, however has sent mixed signals about its approach. While Sessions made favorable comments about the Cole memo earlier this year, in a March speech he referred to marijuana as â€œonly slightly less awfulâ€ than heroin. White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer said in February that states should expect â€œgreater enforcementâ€ of federal marijuana laws. Blumenauer set out to calm nerves this week by holding meetings with cannabis industry representatives in Washington for a lobbying blitz. At a Wednesday press conference on Capitol Hill, Blumenauer and six House colleagues touted a set of bills aimed at allowing cannabis companies access to banking services. While Blumenauer didnâ€™t provide the eventâ€™s best lines â€• that honor went to Rep. Dina Titus (D-Nev.), who quipped that â€œthe industry is not a little head shop with a poster of Che Guevaraâ€ and that Congress needed to â€œpuff puff and passâ€ the bills â€• he was undoubtedly the most animated of the group.â€œUltimately we are going to legalize accessâ€ to marijuana nationwide, Blumenauer, wearing a bow tie patterned with cannabis leaves, told the crowd of journalists and marijuana advocates, â€œbut the main items we can act on now are not controversial.â€ Blumenauer, 68, has been working on the issue since 1972 when, as a state legislator, he helped make Oregon the first state to decriminalize marijuana consumption. This congressional session alone, Blumenauer and three other lawmakers (including two Republicans) launched the Congressional Cannabis Caucus to focus on efforts to liberalize the nationâ€™s marijuana policies. Blumenauer has introduced four bills on the matter and co-sponsored another five â€• legislation that would, among other things, legalize the substance federally and regulate its taxation.If that werenâ€™t enough to burnish his reputation with the cannabis industry, Blumenauer has at least one strain of marijuana named after him, described by the Portland marijuana site The Potlander as a â€œhigh-CBD, low-THC flower grown on a mountainside.â€ It even made the websiteâ€™s list of the yearâ€™s best weed products.After Wednesdayâ€™s press conference, Blumenauer decamped to National Harbor, Maryland, to attend the Marijuana Business Conference and Expo â€• or MJBizCon â€• the nationâ€™s oldest professional gathering for the cannabis industry. Navigating the maze of vendor booths, Blumenauer remained upbeat about the prospects for the industry, insisting that nationwide legalization is four years away, at most.â€œLast fall, in the nine states where marijuana was on the ballot, there were more votes cast for marijuana than for Donald Trump,â€ Blumenauer told HuffPost, â€œand hundreds of thousands of his supporters also supported the legalization effort.â€He speculated that legalization could come about in a number of ways, including through legislation or by executive action from â€œthe new administration that will replace Trumpâ€ that de-lists marijuana as a controlled substance.The sheer normalcy of MJBizCon buttressed Blumenauerâ€™s sunny outlook that widespread legalization of marijuana is inevitable.True, a handful of psychedelic-themed convention booths decorated with rastafarian caricatures could be found, along with an above-average number of steampunk-looking dudes with tiny wireframe glasses and waxed mustaches. Yet aside from the companiesâ€™ preference for green-hued logos and their tendency to incorporate marijuana wordplay into their names (booths belonging to CannaGuard and CannaPro were within shouting distance of one another), MJBizCon resembled any other business conference. It was replete with vendors handing out memory sticks stamped with their companyâ€™s name and throngs of middle-management types exchanging business cards.Indeed, the workaday nature of the proceedings drove home how much whiplash the industry must be experiencing to have developed so far only to have the prospect of bankruptcy, or even jail time, become a possible, if still unlikely, threat. â€œIâ€™m nervous, Iâ€™m really nervous,â€ said Steph Shever, executive director of Americans for Safe Access, a marijuana advocacy group, during a MJBizCon panel on federal drug policy.â€œInvestors have [asked], â€˜Whatâ€™s Trump going to do?â€™â€ said Daniel Macris of Halcyon Organics, a Georgia-based medical marijuana provider, â€œAnd I say, â€˜Dude, I donâ€™t know, whatâ€™s he going to do with anything?â€™â€Blumenauer told HuffPost that cannabis-related companies are â€œconcerned, they want clarity ... because they are investing millions of dollars, theyâ€™re building business, theyâ€™re watching the public support grow, and theyâ€™re apprehensiveâ€ about the Trump administration.He said he believes that strong support for marijuana legalization â€• 60 percent of respondents supported it in one recent poll â€• will stay the administrationâ€™s hand.â€œDonâ€™t give up on the federal government,â€ Blumenauer said during the panel discussion. â€œAfter four decades, I have never been more optimistic.â€â€œThe movement continues to grow, the industry continues to grow,â€ Blumenauer told HuffPost after the panel ended. â€œAnd I think itâ€™s just going to be a case where events will overwhelm.â€JM Rieger contributed reporting to this article. Huffington Post reporter Eliot Nelsonâ€™s book, The Beltway Bible: A Totally Serious A-Z Guide to Our No-Good, Corrupt, Incompetent, Terrible, Depressing and Sometimes Hilarious Government, is out now.

headline: Obamacare Repeal Law Would Give Montana Republican $800,000 Tax Cut
short descr: Greg Gianforte has waffled on the law.
image_caption(s): Greg Gianforte, the Republican candidate for Montanaâ€™s open House seat, stands to benefit financially from the American Health Care Act.
article: Greg Gianforte, the Republican candidate for Montanaâ€™s open House seat, stands to get tax cuts worth nearly $800,000 a year if the House health care bill becomes law, according to a new analysis.The American Health Care Act, as the Republican bill that passed the House of Representatives is known, repeals the two tax hikes on higher earners that the Affordable Care Act used to fund expansion of insurance coverage: a 3.8 percent tax on net investment income and a 0.9 percent increase in the Medicare Hospital Insurance tax. Both taxes apply to individuals making $200,000 a year or more, and married couples making $250,000 a year or more.Based on Gianforteâ€™s average yearly investment and wage income from 2005 to 2014, his annual tax bill would go down $785,413 if the AHCA passed, according to an analysis released Friday by the Center for American Progress Action Fund and Tax March, an organization backed by labor unions and progressive groups.CAP Action Fund senior fellow Seth Hanlon, a tax attorney who worked for former President Barack Obama, conducted the analysis. Hanlon calculated the size of the tax cuts based on the income reported in tax returns for Gianforte and his wife Susan from 2005 to 2014. Gianforte released them as part of his failed bid for governor of Montana in 2016.Gianforte, 56, founded two successful software companies, including RightNow Technologies, which he sold to Oracle for $1.5 billion in 2011.He and his wife made, on average, over $20 million a year in investment income and $1.6 million a year in ordinary wages over the 10-year period for which Gianforte disclosed his earnings. Assuming he continued to maintain this average going forward, he would get a $772,981 annual tax break from repeal of the net investment income tax and another $12,432 from elimination of the Medicare Hospital Insurance surtax.Shane Scanlon, a spokesman for Gianforteâ€™s campaign, did not respond to a request for comment on the lawâ€™s financial benefits for the GOP candidate.Gianforte is hoping to fill a seat that Ryan Zinke vacated when Trump picked him to become interior secretary.He is locked in an increasingly close race with Democrat Rob Quist, 69, a folk music sensation in the state who is running on a populist platform of protecting public lands and making health care more affordable. The special election is this coming Thursday.In the past two weeks, Quist has made an issue out of Gianforteâ€™s murky stance on the Republican health care law, which the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated would deny at least 24 million Americans health insurance. The law would have a significant impact in Montana, where the stateâ€™s uninsured rate dropped from 20 percent in 2012 to 7.4 percent in 2016 thanks to Obamacare.Gianforte told Republican-leaning lobbyists in a private call on May 5 that he was â€œthankfulâ€ that the House had passed the AHCA, according to The New York Times. He has since walked back the comment, telling Montana Public Radio that he would not have voted for the law, because â€œwe donâ€™t have enough data yetâ€ to determine if it would bring down premiums, protect people with pre-existing conditions and maintain access to coverage in rural communities.The latter comments have not deterred Quist in his efforts to paint Gianforte as an unreliable defender of Montanansâ€™ health care. Quist raised $550,000 in the four days following the Times report â€• part of a more than $5 million haul that has come from over 200,000 individual donors.Quistâ€™s campaign has plowed some of that cash into ads hitting Gianforte for voicing support for the law.The campaignâ€™s two closing ads focus on the AHCAâ€™s rollback of federal protections for people with pre-existing medical conditions. The law would allow states to opt out of community rating regulations in Obamacare that require insurers to provide coverage at regional rates for people in the individual insurance market, rather than charge much higher premiums for people with past illness or other health histories the insurance industry has called â€œpre-existing conditions.â€ Those states that choose to opt out would have to create high-risk pools to cover those people, but conservative and liberal experts alike believe the federal funding for those pools would be woefully inadequate.In the ads, Quist discusses his own pre-existing condition from gallbladder surgery, claiming he is one of an estimated half of Montanans who have what would be considered a pre-existing condition.Quist struggled with medical debt for years after the surgery, which was botched and left him unable to afford insurance for a time due to a pre-existing condition. He has said that he supports single-payer health insurance because he does not want people to go bankrupt trying to pay for health care.The CBO has announced that it will release updated estimates of the Republican health legislationâ€™s impact this coming Wednesday. The analysis is expected to show that the current version of the House bill would deprive more people of insurance than the earlier iteration, which preserved more features of Obamacare.Polling in the Montana House race has been sparse, but the available figures suggest Quist has gained ground against Gianforte.A May poll that a Democratic super PAC commissioned has Quist trailing Gianforte by 6 points, compared with an April survey showing him down some 15 points. After initially ignoring the race, the national Democratic Party has taken a greater interest in the past few weeks, with the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee tripling its investment to $600,000 this month.The Republican Party is apparently also taking Quist seriously. President Donald Trumpâ€™s eldest child, Donald Trump Jr., returned to Montana last week to campaign for Gianforte a second time, and Vice President Mike Pence stumped for him last Friday. Apparently the high-profile visits were not enough to stem Quistâ€™s momentum. On Tuesday, influential conservative writer Erick Erickson tweeted that internal Republican polls show Quist made gains in the race over the weekend.Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), whom Quist backed in the 2016 presidential primary, is speaking at events for Quist in Missoula, Butte and Billings on Saturday and in Bozeman on Sunday. Quistâ€™s campaign had to move the Missoula rally to the 7,500-capacity Adams Center arena because of the high level of interest in attending.The story has been updated with the CBOâ€™s announcement that it will soon release new estimates for the American Health Care Act.

headline: We Know Zika Is A Big Problem In Puerto Rico. We Just Don't Know How Big.
short descr: The numbers don't add up.
image_caption(s): The mosquito net-covered stroller where 2-month-old twins Misael and Ismael Carrasquillo slept during a visit for regular vaccinations at Puerto Rico's Concilio de Salud Integral in Loiza in 2016.
article: The Zika virus is still a significant threat to Puerto Rico, even though it has all but disappeared from the U.S. news cycle and, state health officials say, mosquitos in Florida.The climate in Puerto Rico â€• a U.S. territory that has been struggling with a budgetary crisis and has had little intervention from state health programs â€• is ideal for the aedes aegypti mosquitos that spread infectious diseases. There have been 40,000 confirmed Zika cases among residents. All of this could also affect travelers to the island. Little information is coming from Puerto Rico, which could give tourists a misplaced sense of security about the Zika risk there. A JAMA pediatrics study published in October 2016 predicted that Puerto Rico would see 110 to 290 Zika-related microcephaly cases between mid-2016 and mid-2017. Microcephaly is a severe birth defect connected to developmental disabilities and babies being born with smaller-than-average heads.But at last count, Puerto Rican officials had only reported 16 babies born with microcephaly, a staggeringly low figure considering the island has had 3,200 confirmed Zika cases in pregnant women since the beginning of the outbreak. These numbers donâ€™t add up, according to some health officials who talked to health news site Stat under the condition of anonymity. They said Puerto Rico might be underreporting its Zika problem for tourism reasons.The U.S. isnâ€™t keeping track of Zika in Puerto Rico. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention isnâ€™t reporting adverse pregnancy outcomes for U.S. territories â€• and according to the agency website, Puerto Rico is using different criteria to report Zika-related birth defects than the United States is. Itâ€™s also possible that mothers of babies born with birth defects may be unwilling to talk about it publicly. Thereâ€™s a strong stigma surrounding Zika virus, Dr. Carmen Zorrilla, who runs the Maternal Infant Studies Center at the University of Puerto Rico hospital, told NPR. â€œYou have pregnant women with a viral disease that may cause birth defects, which is serious,â€ Zorrilla said. â€œAnd then youâ€™re blaming them for getting it.â€The U.S. had more than 5,200 reported Zika cases as of May 17, including 218 local mosquito-born transmissions in Florida and six such transmissions in Texas, according to the CDC. There have been 1,845 cases of Zika in pregnant women in the U.S., 64 babies born with Zika-related birth defects and eight cases of Zika-related pregnancy loss.The CDC awarded Puerto Ricoâ€™s health department $9.5 million to set up a Zika tracking system for pregnant women and to identify Zika-affected infants and fetuses. But a deep rift between the CDC and Puerto Rican heath officials means the two groups arenâ€™t collaborating, Stat reports. Itâ€™s not clear how long it will take for up-to-date, accurate information about Zika and microcephaly in Puerto Rico to come to light.â€œI see pregnant women every day,â€ Zorrilla told Stat. â€œWhat am I to tell them?â€This reporting is brought to you by HuffPostâ€™s health and science platform, The Scope. Like us on Facebook and Twitter and tell us your story: scopestories@huffingtonpost.com.

headline: Chris Cornellâ€™s Wife Blames Prescription Pills In Heart-Wrenching Statement
short descr: "He loved our children and he would not hurt them by intentionally taking his own life."
image_caption(s): Chris Cornell and Vicky Cornell together in 2006.
article: Vicky Cornell, wife of the late Chris Cornell, released a statement to multiple outlets Friday morning in which she recounted the events leading up to the singerâ€™s death this week and argued that prescription pills played a role in his suicide.â€œAs everyone who knew him commented, Chris was a devoted father and husband,â€ she said. â€œHe was my best friend. His world revolved around his family first and of course, his music, second.â€â€œHe flew home for Motherâ€™s Day to spend time with our family,â€ she continued. â€œHe flew out mid-day Wednesday, the day of the show, after spending time with the children. When we spoke before the show, we discussed plans for a vacation over Memorial Day and other things we wanted to do.â€But when the pair spoke on the phone after his show Wednesday at the Fox Theater in Detroit, she noticed something was off about the singer â€• something fans at the show later said they noticed too. â€œHe was slurring his words; he was different,â€ Vicky said. â€œWhen he told me he may have taken an extra Ativan or two, I contacted security and asked that they check on him.â€Security eventually forced open the door of Chrisâ€™ hotel room at the MGM Grand Casino, where they found him unreponsive on the floor of the bathroom Cornell. A medical examiner later determined that the singerâ€™s cause of death was â€œsuicide by hanging.â€â€œWhat happened is inexplicable and I am hopeful that further medical reports will provide additional details. I know that he loved our children and he would not hurt them by intentionally taking his own life,â€ Vicky said. Cornell family attorney Kirk Pasich said in a separate statement Friday that they believe the extra Ativan, which can lead to suicidal thoughts, potentially caused Cornell to take his life.â€œWithout the results of toxicology tests, we do not know what was going on with Chris â€” or if any substances contributed to his demise,â€ Pasich said. Chris, a recovering addict, had a prescription for Ativan and mightâ€™ve taken more than the recommended dosage.â€œThe family believes that if Chris took his life, he did not know what he was doing and that drugs or other substances may have affected his actions,â€ Pasich added.Vicky also took the time in her statement to thank Chrisâ€™ fans for the kind words they have offered since the news of the Soundgarden singerâ€™s death Thursday morning.â€œChrisâ€™s death is a loss that escapes words and has created an emptiness in my heart that will never be filled,â€ she said. â€œThe outpouring of love and support from his fans, friends, and family means so much more to us than anyone can know,â€ she said. â€œThank you for that, and for understanding how difficult this is for us.â€ If you or someone you know needs help, call 1-800-273-8255 for the National  Suicide Prevention Lifeline. You can also text HELLO to 741-741 for free, 24-hour support from the Crisis Text Line. Outside of the U.S., please visit the International Association for Suicide Prevention for a database of resources.

headline: Trump's On The Verge Of Exploding The Health Insurance Market
short descr: The government owes money to insurance companies. Trump reportedly doesn't want to pay.
image_caption(s): President Donald Trump has been threatening to kill cost-sharing reduction payments for months.
article: President Donald Trump has had his finger on the detonator of the bomb to blow up Obamacare for months. Now he may be about to press it.Trump told advisers earlier this week that he wants to cut off billions of dollars in payments to health insurance companies that serve the poorest enrollees in the Affordable Care Act exchanges, Politico reported Friday. If Trump follows through on this threat, he could wreak havoc on the health insurance system. Insurance companies are likely to hike premiums or to stop selling to people who buy coverage via the exchanges, like HealthCare.gov and Covered California, or directly (rather than obtaining coverage through their employers or government programs like Medicare and Medicaid).The results would be higher prices and fewer, if any, choices for consumers, and the effects could be felt quickly because many states would allow insurers to drop their customers right away in the absence of these payments. In short, this part of the health insurance market could fall apart under Trumpâ€™s watch if he doesnâ€™t pay the money the federal government owes.At issue are whatâ€™s called cost-sharing reduction payments â€• these are essentially reimbursements to health insurance companies, which are required to reduce out-of-pocket costs like deductibles and copayments for low-income customers. A pending lawsuit brought by House Republicans against the Obama administration in 2014 has challenged the legality of these CSR payments.â€œThe White House has told Congress that it will make the May CSR, but has not made any commitment on further payments. No final decisions have been made at this time, and all options are on the table,â€ a White House official wrote Friday in an email to HuffPost.The White Houseâ€™s caginess about these payments has driven health care and business groups to seek relief from the legislative branch.â€œWe urge Congress to take action now to guarantee a steady stream of CSR funding through 2018. Such action would represent a strong, positive step for all consumers who buy their own insurance by eliminating the single most destabilizing factor causing double-digit premium increases for 2018,â€ reads a letter sent to Senate leaders on Friday from a coalition including the American Medical Association, the American Hospital Association, Americaâ€™s Health Insurance Plans, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other health care, business and patient advocacy groups. â€œAt this point, only Congressional action can help consumers.â€Health insurance companies, state regulators, governors and congressional Democrats have been on edge about the exchange markets since Trump said during a pre-inauguration press conference in January that â€œthe easiest thing would be to let it implode in â€™17 and believe me, weâ€™d get pretty much whatever we wanted.â€Trump has made similar comments many times since becoming president, including during an interview with the Economist this month. â€œWeâ€™re subsidizing it and we donâ€™t have to subsidize it. You know if I ever stop wanting to pay the subsidies, which I will,â€ he told the Economist. Trump has also inaccurately referred to this money as a â€œbailoutâ€ of the insurance industry, rather than as a reimbursement of money the government owes insurers.According to the Los Angeles Times, a senior Trump health official told insurers that the administration would promise to make these payments if the industry backed the health care bill the House passed last month â€• a quid pro quo offer that the administration denies.To Trumpâ€™s thinking, dealing this major blow to Obamacare could force Democrats to the negotiating table over repeal of the entire Affordable Care Act. Congressional Democrats have loudly rejected that idea.Whatâ€™s more, 60 percent of Americans donâ€™t approve of negotiating tactics that disrupt insurance markets, according to an April survey by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Nearly three-fourths think Trump should work to keep the Affordable Care Act running while Congress considers a new health care law, and almost two-thirds â€• including a majority of Republicans â€• believe Trump and the GOP are responsible for any future problems with Obamacare.Yet Trump, against the advice of Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price and others, still favors cutting off the cost-sharing payments, Politico reported.And the Trump administration could make its intentions known in mere days.The Obama administration had appealed a trial court judgeâ€™s ruling in favor of House Republicansâ€™ claims that the federal government is unlawfully making those payments without an explicit congressional appropriation. In the meantime, the judge allowed the Obama and then Trump administrations to continue reimbursing insurers.The appeals court has granted delays in the case this year as the Trump administration pondered what to do. But now the two parties face a deadline of Monday to update the court on their plans.Congress could resolve the issue at any time by simply appropriating the funding, but it hasnâ€™t.Exchange enrollees earning up to 250 percent of the federal poverty level â€• which amounts to $30,015 for a single person â€• are eligible for cost reductions, which can transform deductibles of thousands of dollars into just hundreds of dollars for the consumer. The Affordable Care Act mandates that insurers pay the cost difference to medical providers and subsequently get paid back by the federal government themselves. More than 7 million people â€• 58 percent of exchange enrollees â€• received the subsidies this year.The cost-sharing reduction payments are crucial to the finances of insurance companies. Without this money, insurers would raise premiums by an average of 19 percent next year, on top of whatever the increases otherwise would have been, the Kaiser Family Foundation estimated. Early rate filings in several states are consistent with those projections, which some insurers citing uncertainty about the cost-sharing reduction payments as a reason theyâ€™re asking for higher premiums next year.During his early months in office, Trump has gone out of his way to raise insurance companiesâ€™ concerns about whether they would ever get their money. The consequence has been heightened confusion and worry in the health insurance industry, as state officials complain they canâ€™t get straight answers from the Trump administration.The White House threatened to cut off the money during negotiations with Congress over a spending bill in April, but relented. Still, Trump has never stopped talking about it, to the consternation of the health care industry and state officials.In letters delivered Wednesday, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, which represents state officials from both political parties, urged Senate leaders and the White House Office of Management and Budget to make sure the money doesnâ€™t stop flowing. The bipartisan National Governors Association asked Congress to address the cost-sharing reduction payments last month.â€œThe time to act is now,â€ Wisconsin insurance commissioner Theodore Nickel and Tennessee insurance commissioner Julie Mix McPeak wrote Wednesday on behalf of the insurance commissioners group to OMB Director Mick Mulvaney. It was Mulvaney who issued the April threat to halt the payments.â€œCarriers are currently developing their rates for 2018 and making the decision whether to participate on the exchanges, or even off the exchanges, in 2018. Assurances from the administration that the cost-sharing reduction payments will continue under current law will go a long way toward stabilizing the individual markets in our states while legislative replacement and reform options are debated in Congress,â€ Nickel and McPeak wrote.Trump, as the Politico report indicates, doesnâ€™t seem inclined to provide those assurances or to take any steps to manage the insurance markets that his government is responsible for overseeing.Sam Stein contributed reporting.

headline: Barack Obama's Leather Jacket Has Been Hiding In His Closet This Whole Time
short descr: We should have known.

article: In a twist that should come as a surprise to no one, it turns out Barack Obamaâ€™s stellar sense of style â€• the one heâ€™s been unknowingly using to tug at our heart strings for months â€• has been waiting to emerge for quite some time. headline: Lawmakers Are Taking Action To Make TV And Film More Diverse
short descr: Hiring more women and minorities might soon be a money-saver.
image_caption(s): From left, â€œSEAL Teamâ€ star David Boreanaz, â€œMe, Myself & Iâ€ star Bobby Moynihan, â€œWisdom of the Crowdâ€ star Jeremy Piven and â€œ9JKLâ€ star Mark Feuerstein, all coming to CBS.
article: This week, CBS announced itâ€™d be adding eight new shows to its fall TV slate that include not one leading lady. As CBS Corp. CEO Leslie Moonves explained to a skeptical reporter, â€œthe best pilots win at the end of the day.â€Apparently, executives at the network were having trouble finding quality shows that spotlight characters who arenâ€™t majority white men. If thatâ€™s the case, some state legislators might soon be able to lend them a hand.Lawmakers in New York are moving forward with a bill that would encourage TV production in the state to hire women and minority writers and directors in order to â€œenhance the diversity of stories and casts.â€ Behind-the-scenes hires can have a big effect: Research has shown that hiring more women and minorities in such roles affects diversity in the end product on screens everywhere. And on-screen representation is good for everyone.Many states, including California, Illinois and Georgia, have tax credit programs aimed to encourage film industry production for jobs and tourism. Most of â€œThe Walking Dead,â€ for example, is shot in Georgia. â€œThe Americans,â€ despite being set in Washington, D.C., shoots in New York City. Hundreds of writers, including Tina Fey and members of the Writers Guild of America, have written in support of the New York bill, Deadline reported earlier this month. (HuffPost is unionized under the auspices of the WGA-East, a sister organization of the WGA-West.) Sponsored by Sen. Marisol Alcantara and assembly member Marcos Crespo, the measure would earmark $5 million of its $420 million program to pay the salaries of women and minority writers and directors on TV shows. The hope is that by targeting TV shows, produced more quickly and in greater number, the bill will have a larger impact.â€œAs an Afro-Latina immigrant, I knew what it felt like to grow up feeling invisible in American culture,â€ Alcantara told HuffPost. â€œIt was so rare to see a character of color on television, and when you did see one, it felt like they were tokenized, stereotyped or killed off quickly. I think the overall quality of television, the different kinds of stories that can be told, the overall landscape of the art form will benefit greatly from having opportunities for diverse people to tell their stories, which I believe this legislation will provide.â€ If passed, effectiveness of the diversity provisions would remain to be seen. To professor Darnell Hunt, director of the UCLAâ€™s Ralph J. Bunche Center for African American Studies, legal measures are â€œan important tool in the toolboxâ€ to increase on-screen diversity. But they may not go far enough.â€œIt strikes me as maybe a bit too little. I think maybe they could set aside a little more, when itâ€™s such a huge problem in the industry,â€ Hunt said about the lack of on-screen representation, adding, â€œgiven how these tax credit programs are proven to work.â€Despite the uncertain impact, other legislators are also thinking about what they can do to help.Some lawmakers in California, where a $330 million tax credit program aims to keep production in the film industryâ€™s homeland, are mulling additions similar to the ones gaining steam on the opposite coast. Back in February, state assembly members Sebastian Ridley-Thomas and Kensan Chu held a hearing aimed to determine whether adding diversity provisions to the program would actually affect diversity â€• both behind the camera and in front of it. Such measures are still under consideration. Other states are focused on diversity in film crews and other non-creator roles, although the influence of those guidelines on what we see on screen would be much smaller. In Georgia, once likened to the Hollywood of the South, a state representative held a hearing last November to consider adding provisions aimed at diversity, while Illinois already holds a diversity requirement in its state film tax credit program. Applicants there must submit paperwork proving diversity in production crews and production office hires. New Yorkâ€™s bill has a long road ahead of it: After its introduced in the stateâ€™s senate and assembly, it needs to pass there before finally landing on the desk of Gov. Andrew Cuomo. But with a record number of shows filmed there, nudging studios toward greater inclusion could give CBS â€• and others â€• more top-notch options next time around.Welcome to Battleground, where art and activism meet.

headline: ESPN's Holly Rowe Says Her Cancer Has Returned
short descr: The network has renewed her contract as she battles cancer and keeps working.
image_caption(s): Holly Rowe, pictured with Kansas guard Frank Mason III in February, thanked ESPN for renewing her contract amid her cancer battle.
article: ESPN reporter Holly Rowe says her cancer has returned and spread, The Associated Press reported.â€œI donâ€™t think about having cancer when Iâ€™m out here,â€ Rowe told AP before she worked the sideline Thursday for a WNBA game between the Minnesota Lynx and host New York Liberty. â€œMonday, I have a CAT scan and have treatment. Iâ€™ll be a cancer patient on Monday. Iâ€™m not thinking about it today.â€These are tough times for the sports network. Kathy Berman, wife of Chris Berman, who is arguably the face of the network, died in a car crash last week. The outlet has also conducted massive layoffs.But Rowe will not be among them. ESPN stated Thursday in an editorâ€™s note to a personal essay by the reporter that her contract had been renewed.â€œI promise to repay and thank my bosses at ESPN for sticking by me during the most difficult year of my life,â€ she wrote. â€œI donâ€™t take a single moment of this journey for granted.â€In February 2016, doctors removed a tumor from her chest for the second time within a year, according to Sports Illustrated. She has continued to work during her battle with a rare form of melanoma.â€œWhen I say sports have saved my life, Iâ€™m not saying that as a joke or lightly,â€ she told her hometown paper, the Salt Lake Tribune, recently. â€œItâ€™s given me things to look forward to and every single event I get to, someone is winning or losing.â€Rowe became a regular presence on ESPN in 1998.

headline: If You Want To Be Healthier, Eat Your Trash
short descr: A lot of the food we throw out is edible -- and loaded with nutrients.
image_caption(s): A new report concludes that Americans are missing out on critical nutrients -- even as we're throwing copious amounts of calories into the trash.
article: One manâ€™s trash is another manâ€™s vitamin-rich meal.Itâ€™s long been known that we throw out a ridiculous amount of edible food in the United States. But a new report from the Journal of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics has uncovered just how many critical nutrients weâ€™re discarding with our trash. Whatâ€™s particularly concerning is that these are the very nutrients most Americans â€• both rich and poor â€• arenâ€™t getting enough of.â€œWasted food in the U.S. contains a staggering amount of nutrients, especially nutrients that we tend to under-consume,â€ Marie Spiker, one of the studyâ€™s authors, said in a video released alongside the report.In 2012, the amount of food Americans discarded was enough to provide 2,000 calories a day to 84 percent of the countryâ€™s adult population, according to the report. That same year, 15.9 percent of Americans struggled to buy food at times, per the Department of Agriculture. On top of this problem, the new report finds, Americans arenâ€™t getting the recommended intake of certain nutrients including dietary fiber, calcium, potassium, and vitamins A, C, D, and E.â€œSome of the most important foods for people to eat are relatively low in calories,â€ Roni Neff, another author of the report, added. â€œLooking at items like vitamin D or fiber really help get a picture of the foods that we need to consume more of that are going right into the landfill.â€The authors of the report analyzed two data sets from the USDA to calculate the nutritional value of food waste at retail and consumer levels in 2012.Hereâ€™s what they noticed about fiber, for example: The recommended daily fiber intake for a woman is 25 grams, yet women in America consume just 8.9 grams; meanwhile, the country squanders vast quantities of fiber-rich foods, enough to feed 74 million women their daily recommended amount of the nutrient.One of the main reasons tons of healthful foods end up in landfills is because theyâ€™re not considered pretty enough to sell. Half of the produce grown in the U.S. is trashed because itâ€™s bruised, misshapen, discolored or has some other deformity thatâ€™s non-threatening, according to a study conducted by The Guardian.While thereâ€™s been a push in recent years for retailers to promote so-called â€œuglyâ€ fruits and vegetables, theyâ€™re still being squandered at an alarming rate.Admittedly, only a small portion of discarded food can be rescued, the authors of the report noted. They, instead, are encouraging efforts to prevent food waste from happening in the first place.A number of advocates and lawmakers agree and have been shaping initiatives to accomplish that very goal.A member of the New York City Council recently proposed a bill that would develop a Craigslist-style website for food waste. At the end of each business day, supermarkets and restaurants would post the types of edible foods they have left over but canâ€™t sell. Food pantries and soup kitchens could see whatâ€™s available and pick up the products they need.Rafael Espinal Jr., who introduced the measure, hopes the City Council will vote on the bill in the next few months, and that the website will be up and running by next year.â€œThese are hungry New Yorkers who are just looking for a meal to get through the next day,â€ Espinal told HuffPost earlier this month of the people who would benefit from the site. â€œThey donâ€™t have the luxury that everyday New Yorkers have when it comes to choosing what theyâ€™re eating.â€

headline: Meet The Openly Gay Alabama Environmentalist Running To Replace Jeff Sessions
authors: J.W. Holland, ContributorPolitical Writer and Editor
short descr: In a state whose politics is ruled by evangelical conservatives can Michael Hansen win their votes?
image_caption(s): Is Michael Hansen the breath of fresh air Alabama and America needs?
article: Openly gay, executive director of an anti-air pollution health advocacy group, and a Democrat. Any of those descriptions would make it difficult to win a U.S. Senate special election in Alabama. Combine them all, you have Michael Hansen, and he intends to do just that.In a field of 19 seeking the seat, Hansen is one of eight Democrats running for that partyâ€™s nomination. When asked how he, in a GOP controlled state, would stand out in such a large group Hansen said that his experience in working with government bodies on drafting different pieces of legislations and ordinances gave him an inside look at how to get things done.He also pointed to the lack of trustworthy leadership within the state recently â€œWeâ€™ve had our share of corrupt politicians here, especially lately.â€ Referring to the recent scandal and resignation of Gov. Robert Bentley, and corruption conviction of Speaker of the House Mike Hubbard who has sentenced to prison. It also includes Chief Justice Roy Mooreâ€™s suspension for ordering State Judges to ignore the U.S. Supreme Court ruling on same-sex marriage. â€œI think people are sick and tired of that sort of business as usual, shady politics and corruption,â€ adding â€œmy record of integrity is pretty impeccable.â€Hansen is well aware of the uphill battle he is facing in the state, especially with conservative evangelicals who make up a huge portion of the voters in Alabama. â€œI grew up in Memphis Tennessee, in a conservative, Republican, Christian, Southern Baptist home,â€ he said, â€œthat was my life, I thought I was going to end up in the ministry. So I understand the Christian faith.â€ He continued â€œWhat I know though, there are gay kids in those homes all over the state.â€ He said while many of them donâ€™t have it easy, a large number of them do have families who love and accept them and once it involves someone in their family people are much more likely to be receptive. â€œIâ€™m optimistic that if people get to know me, they will be willing to have a conversation.â€His group, GASP, is an Alabama-based non-profit whose mission is to reduce air pollution focused on major sources of pollution like power plants and other large industry. Speaking about his environmental stance in a state that has a significant history in coal production Hansen said, â€œThe reality is everyone has to breath clean air, has to have clean water to drink a safe place to live and make sure the food they eat isnâ€™t going to poison them.â€ He added, â€œThat is a universal thing; I donâ€™t think that is a liberal thing,â€ and â€œitâ€™s not contrary to conservative values to talk about taking care of our planet.â€Commenting directly about those currently employed in the industry in his state â€œIâ€™m a big fan of coal miners,â€ he said, â€œI think they do wonderful work that is a real sacrifice.â€ He then noted, â€œBut the reality is we are moving away from coal, and we have to take care of the people who have made that sacrifice.â€ He went on to say that you can talk about the environmental impact and support those communities at the same time.Hansen says that a face to face showdown with Ten Commandments Judge Roy Moore would be his dream matchup this fall. â€œI want to be all about empathy and kindness,â€ something he says is lacking in our culture, â€œRoy Moore is the opposite of all that.â€ Saying that Mooreâ€™s brand of vitriol is the kind of rhetoric that makes gay kids hate themselves. â€œThatâ€™s what I want to fight against, the perception that that is all Alabama is.â€ He wants to be face to face with Moore to say â€œWeâ€™re here, weâ€™re not going anywhere, and weâ€™re people too.â€ He said Roy Moore in his opinion does not represent conservatism or Christian values at all. Continuing to say that â€œIf people have a problem with that, I would say, Itâ€™s 2017 letâ€™s get on with it, and letâ€™s talk about policy.â€On illegal immigration and its impact on the state, particularly in agriculture, he said, â€œImmigrants are an important part of not just our nationâ€™s history but our current system.â€ Saying we need to make sure we are treating immigrants well, â€œLike humans and not like slaves.â€ Pointing to the passage in 2011 of HB56, an anti-immigrant law in Alabama, Hansen said that farmers in his state ended up suffering because of a lack of labor to help bring in their crops. He wants to work toward comprehensive immigration reform and paths to citizenship. â€œNot building a wall and deporting millions of people.â€ which he called both inhumane and an absurd waste of money.To many, the biggest hurdle he has to come is his party affiliation. In Alabama, the GOP controls all of the statewide offices and all but one of its current nine delegation members in Washington is Republican. When asked how he would overcome that kind of obstacle Hansen said in Alabama â€œThereâ€™s an opportunity because of the corruption on the Republican side of the aisle that people are fed up with.â€ He continued â€œDonald Trump is doing everything he can to make it easier for us.â€ But mainly he said that his understanding of struggle in the working class blue-collar communities like he grew up in would help his message reach those voters. â€œI get it, Iâ€™ve worked three jobs before and had to make a choice between prescriptions and groceries.â€Speaking about his partyâ€™s recent history in the state he said, â€œNot just me, but Democrats have to talk to people and listen to their concerns,â€ and his party needed to, â€œtailor their policies to the things that impact peopleâ€™s lives, not just the left vs. right policy making.â€ Emphasizing a need to make sure that people have their basic needs met and they have a chance at a good life. A message that he believes will resonate with voters in the state. â€œI donâ€™t think we have enough listening.â€As an Alabama native myself, I can understand the skepticism many have about his candidacy. It, however, isnâ€™t unheard of for an openly gay candidate to win there. Patricia Todd was elected to the Alabama House in 2006 as the first openly gay candidate in the history of the state and has been reelected twice.Michael Hansen isnâ€™t going in blind here, and he knows the difficulties he will encounter in filling the seat formerly held by current Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Knowing that, Hansenâ€™s campaign may just be the breath of fresh air Alabama, and indeed the nation, desperately needs.Photo Credit: Michael Hansen for Alabama Facebook Page

headline: Controversial Puerto Rican Nationalist Oscar Lopez Rivera Returns To Chicago
short descr: The leader of pro-independence group FALN served 35 years in prison before President Barack Obama commuted his sentence.
image_caption(s): Oscar Lopez Rivera supporter Moses Cintron holds a photo of his truck painted with supportive messages.
article: CHICAGO â€• Throughout many of the 35 years that Puerto Rican nationalist icon Oscar Lopez Rivera was behind bars, residents of one Chicago neighborhood saw him every day.Murals and sun-bleached images of Lopez Rivera plastered windows along the â€œPaseo Boricuaâ€ in Chicagoâ€™s Puerto Rican enclave of Humboldt Park with messages that called for his freedom and hailed him as a hero for his controversial role in fighting for Puerto Rican independence. Lopez Rivera spent part of his boyhood in the neighborhood.On Thursday, Rivera, 74, was given a heroâ€™s welcome in Chicago, just one day after he was released from house arrest in San Juan, where he served out the remainder of his time after former President Barack Obama commuted his 55-year sentence in January. Thursdayâ€™s events included a march down the Paseo Boricua accompanied by Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D-Ill.) and other Latino politicians in Chicago, bands, a flotilla and a reception in the park. Some of Lopez Riveraâ€™s older supporters thought neither they nor Rivera would live to see him walk free. Others, like Moses Cintron, 68, simply felt relief after supporting Lopez Rivera for at least 20 years.Cintron and his wife, Lourdes, drove in from Cleveland to see Lopez Rivera, whom he had visited several times while Lopez Rivera was in federal prison in Indiana. He carried with him a picture of an old pickup truck that he had emblazoned with messages of support for Lopez Rivera. His current truck simply says â€œFree Oscarâ€ on the sides. â€œThose letters have been on my pickup the last five years,â€ Cintron said. Rivera was sentenced in 1981 for his involvement with pro-Puerto Rican independence militant group Armed Forces of National Liberation, or FALN (and was later sentenced to an additional 15 years for allegedly plotting an escape).The group was linked to more than 100 bombings that injured dozens and killed five in cities like Chicago and New York. Though Lopez Rivera was never directly linked to specific bombings, he was convicted on multiple charges that included seditious conspiracy, or plotting to overthrow the U.S. government. President Bill Clinton offered Lopez Rivera and other FALN members clemency in 1999, but Lopez Rivera rejected it because it would not include all of the imprisoned associates. Even with the Obama commutation, Lopez Rivera was one of the longest-serving political prisoners in the world. He received support for his pardon from high-profile figures like Pope Francis, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and â€œHamiltonâ€ creator Lin-Manuel Miranda.Some, like Cappy Kidd of Chicago, thought Lopez Riveraâ€™s sentence was unfairly harsh.â€œThey kept him in prison all these years because he wouldnâ€™t give up his support,â€ Kidd said. But others, notably family members of the victims who were injured or killed in the FALN bombings, have been outraged not only by Obamaâ€™s clemency move, but also by the intense support of Lopez Rivera, whom they regard as a terrorist.Joe Connor, whose father, Frank, was killed in the 1975 bombing at the historic Fraunces Tavern in Manhattan, spoke to NPR in January after Lopez Riveraâ€™s commutation was announced. â€œIâ€™m hearing heâ€™s a freedom fighter. Heâ€™s done all these things. Heâ€™s not violent. But what did he do if not being a terrorist?â€ Connor said. â€œThereâ€™s no answer to it because he was a terrorist.â€Connor, who was just 9 when his father was killed, was similarly furious over the move by Humboldt Parkâ€™s Puerto Rican alderman, Roberto Maldonado, to grant Lopez Rivera an honorary street sign in the neighborhood. Connor told the Chicago Sun-Times in February that the designation was â€œa direct insult to my fatherâ€™s life.â€ Melissa Duprey, a 32-year-old from Chicago, views Lopez Rivera as an important example for young people, reminding them to organize and work for the change they want to see in their communities.Duprey was more skeptical of the politicians who came out for his homecoming, and assessed their motives as opportunistic and ultimately undedicated to Lopez Riveraâ€™s ideals.For Veronica Tirado, a 25-year-old who recently moved to Chicago from Puerto Rico, Lopez Rivera remains an inspiring and potent symbol for young people on the island â€• to which Lopez Rivera eventually plans to return â€• and in the U.S. â€œHis work teaches me that we as a diaspora can make change,â€ Tirado said. On the island, Tirado said, university students and teachers have been fighting the severe austerity measures that have chopped education budgets. Lopez Rivera, she said, remains relevant because â€œhe still gives us hope.â€

Lopez Rivera spent part of his boyhood in the neighborhood.On Thursday, Rivera, 74, was given a heroâ€™s welcome in Chicago, just one day after he was released from house arrest in San Juan, where he served out the remainder of his time after former President Barack Obama commuted his 55-year sentence in January. Thursdayâ€™s events included a march down the Paseo Boricua accompanied by Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D-Ill.) and other Latino politicians in Chicago, bands, a flotilla and a reception in the park. Some of Lopez Riveraâ€™s older supporters thought neither they nor Rivera would live to see him walk free. Others, like Moses Cintron, 68, simply felt relief after supporting Lopez Rivera for at least 20 years.Cintron and his wife, Lourdes, drove in from Cleveland to see Lopez Rivera, whom he had visited several times while Lopez Rivera was in federal prison in Indiana. He carried with him a picture of an old pickup truck that he had emblazoned with messages of support for Lopez Rivera. His current truck simply says â€œFree Oscarâ€ on the sides. â€œThose letters have been on my pickup the last five years,â€ Cintron said. Rivera was sentenced in 1981 for his involvement with pro-Puerto Rican independence militant group Armed Forces of National Liberation, or FALN (and was later sentenced to an additional 15 years for allegedly plotting an escape).The group was linked to more than 100 bombings that injured dozens and killed five in cities like Chicago and New York. Though Lopez Rivera was never directly linked to specific bombings, he was convicted on multiple charges that included seditious conspiracy, or plotting to overthrow the U.S. government. President Bill Clinton offered Lopez Rivera and other FALN members clemency in 1999, but Lopez Rivera rejected it because it would not include all of the imprisoned associates. Even with the Obama commutation, Lopez Rivera was one of the longest-serving political prisoners in the world. He received support for his pardon from high-profile figures like Pope Francis, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and â€œHamiltonâ€ creator Lin-Manuel Miranda.Some, like Cappy Kidd of Chicago, thought Lopez Riveraâ€™s sentence was unfairly harsh.â€œThey kept him in prison all these years because he wouldnâ€™t give up his support,â€ Kidd said. But others, notably family members of the victims who were injured or killed in the FALN bombings, have been outraged not only by Obamaâ€™s clemency move, but also by the intense support of Lopez Rivera, whom they regard as a terrorist.Joe Connor, whose father, Frank, was killed in the 1975 bombing at the historic Fraunces Tavern in Manhattan, spoke to NPR in January after Lopez Riveraâ€™s commutation was announced. â€œIâ€™m hearing heâ€™s a freedom fighter. Heâ€™s done all these things. Heâ€™s not violent. But what did he do if not being a terrorist?â€ Connor said. â€œThereâ€™s no answer to it because he was a terrorist.â€Connor, who was just 9 when his father was killed, was similarly furious over the move by Humboldt Parkâ€™s Puerto Rican alderman, Roberto Maldonado, to grant Lopez Rivera an honorary street sign in the neighborhood. Connor told the Chicago Sun-Times in February that the designation was â€œa direct insult to my fatherâ€™s life.â€ Melissa Duprey, a 32-year-old from Chicago, views Lopez Rivera as an important example for young people, reminding them to organize and work for the change they want to see in their communities.Duprey was more skeptical of the politicians who came out for his homecoming, and assessed their motives as opportunistic and ultimately undedicated to Lopez Riveraâ€™s ideals.For Veronica Tirado, a 25-year-old who recently moved to Chicago from Puerto Rico, Lopez Rivera remains an inspiring and potent symbol for young people on the island â€• to which Lopez Rivera eventually plans to return â€• and in the U.S. â€œHis work teaches me that we as a diaspora can make change,â€ Tirado said. On the island, Tirado said, university students and teachers have been fighting the severe austerity measures that have chopped education budgets. Lopez Rivera, she said, remains relevant because â€œhe still gives us hope.â€

headline: U.S. Government Abruptly Removes Damning Detention Inspection Report From Its Website
authors: Christina Fialho, ContributorCo-Founder/Executive Director, Freedom for Immigrants (formerl...
short descr: On May 9, 2017, the Orange County Board of Supervisors voted to increase its contract with U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement
image_caption(s): Originally published by the Office of Inspector General (2017).
article: On May 9, 2017, the Orange County Board of Supervisors voted to increase its contract with U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) to detain 120 more immigrants at Theo Lacy Facility. This contract increase comes just two months after the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) released a damning report on its unannounced inspection of Theo Lacy. Mysteriously, OIGâ€™s report was immediately removed from the governmentâ€™s website after the May 9th vote.In the report, which now can be read on Community Initiatives for Visiting Immigrants in Confinement (CIVIC)â€™s website, OIG found that Theo Lacy Facility was not complying with the U.S. Department of Agricultureâ€™s safe food handling guidelines, resulting in people in immigration detention being served spoiled meat. Theo Lacy Facility also was not complying with ICEâ€™s Performance Based National Detention Standards, resulting in people being wrongfully held in a form of solitary confinement for long periods of time. OIG offered a number of recommendations in its report, but there is no evidence that the Orange County Sheriffâ€™s Department or ICE have implemented these recommendations. In fact, CIVIC continues to document people in immigration detention at Theo Lacy being improperly placed in disciplinary segregation units that violate ICEâ€™s standards. We also continue to hear stories from people currently detained at Theo Lacy about spoiled food.Perhaps even more alarming, CIVIC has documented multiple instances of physical abuse of people in immigration detention by the Orange County Sheriffâ€™s Department (OCSD). As recent as this month, we have received complaints from people in immigration detention in Orange County who have been physically and verbally abused by OCSD. The decision by the Orange County Board of Supervisors to increase the contract with ICE is irresponsible. It is past time to end immigration detention in Orange County, California.
